title: Amid SNAP benefit cuts, these Greater Boston food businesses are here to help
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Greater Boston food businesses are offering support amid SNAP benefit cuts due to the federal government shutdown.
Initiatives include free meals, community fridges, and discounted meal deals for those with SNAP cards and federal workers.
Local establishments participating include American Flatbread, Blacker's Bakeshop, Seoul Kitchen, and Suya Joint, among others.

title: Karen Read shuffles defense attorney lineup in wrongful death suit
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Karen Read changes her defense team in a wrongful death suit filed by John O’Keefe's family.
Read's new defense attorneys from Tang & Maravelis replace those from Melick & Porter who withdrew.
Despite acquittal of murder, Read faces civil claims; she'll sue witnesses and state police for conspiracy.

title: FuGaKyu in Brookline closes after 27 years in business
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: FuGaKyu, a Japanese restaurant in Brookline, is closing on November 5, ending 27 years of operation.
The restaurant, which opened in 1998, was known for its sushi menu and traditional shoji decor.
FuGaKyu previously had locations in Lynnfield and Sudbury, both of which have also closed.

title: Halsey hospitalized with ‘minor medical emergency’ in between Boston shows
author: Heather Alterisio
bullets: Halsey hospitalized for a minor medical emergency between sold-out Boston shows at MGM Music Hall at Fenway.
She was treated at Massachusetts General Hospital and praised the medical team for their care.
The artist has addressed past health issues including lupus and a T-cell lymphoproliferative disorder.

title: 18-year-old killed in Belmont moped crash
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: 18-year-old from Watertown killed after moped crash with SUV in Belmont on Tuesday morning.
Moped was seen driving erratically and failed to stop for police before colliding with a Honda CRV.
Driver of SUV sustained minor injuries; moped rider died at the hospital. Investigation is ongoing.

title: Feds: Nurse replaced liquid oxy with household cleaner
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: Lori Robertson, nurse from Salem, New Hampshire, pleaded not guilty to tampering with a patient's oxycodone prescription.
Robertson allegedly replaced a hospice patient's liquid oxycodone with household cleaner at an Amesbury facility on March 31.
She faces a federal charge of tampering with a consumer product and is released on probation pending a Nov. 24 court date.

title: AG Campbell skeptical of proposed law to ban ICE agents from wearing masks
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: AG Andrea Campbell questioned the effectiveness of a state law banning ICE agents from wearing masks in Massachusetts.
State Rep. Jim Hawkins sponsored a bill to prohibit law enforcement from masking identities during public interactions.
Campbell urged federal-level action, critiquing U.S. Attorney Leah Foley's office for inaction on holding ICE accountable.

title: Birds of Paradise, Brighton’s travel-themed cocktail bar, closes at the Speedway
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: Birds of Paradise, a travel-themed cocktail bar at the Charles River Speedway in Brighton, closed on October 31.
Ran Duan's Birds of Paradise, known for its global cocktail menu, opened in 2022 and closed after two years.
Duan transferred overseeing the bar amid a police investigation into an incident at his home; no charges were filed.

title: Child struck by school bus, driver arrested in Medway
author: Madison Lucchesi
bullets: A child on a bike was struck by a school bus near Francis J. Burke Memorial Elementary School, Medway, Tuesday morning.
Driver Kenneth Benjamin, 69, was arrested for disorderly conduct after an altercation following the crash, police reported.
Benjamin was cited for failing to stop at a crosswalk and arraigned in Wrentham District Court on the same day.

title: TD Bank plans to shutter 6 Mass. branches amid nationwide closures
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: TD Bank plans to close six branches and one remote drive-thru in Massachusetts as part of 51 nationwide closures.
TD Bank's closures aim to strengthen its U.S. retail presence via store enhancements, digital banking, and personalized services.
Despite previous legal issues, TD Bank reports a $3.3 billion earnings bounce back after last year's $181 million loss.
